intro: Charlwoodia longifolia, commonly known as the long-leaved charlwood, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its elongated, lance-shaped leaves and showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in summer. It typically grows in wetlands and along the edges of ponds, thriving in moist, sandy soils. Charlwoodia longifolia is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for wildlife.
